captions.text:
This episode of Film Riot is brought to you
by Domain.com. Today's episode of Film Riot

is just downright epic. Welcome to Film Riot.
Facilitates the affects and the technique,

score some of the latest Hollywood films.
I'm you're host, Ryan Connolly. So question,

what does the latest Pirates of the Caribbean,
the new Spiderman and the film The Peter Jackson
is currently shooting have in common?

Correct. They're all shot with the Red Epic
which is the camera I have right here to show

you guys today. This is unfortunately not
my camera. I actually have to send it back

very soon. It was sent to us, on loan from
Eric Kessler, who is behind the awesome Kessler

Crane gear, and we're lucky enough to be one
of his Kessler's Shooters.

So, here it is. So, again enormous thank you
to Mr. Kessler for letting us play with his

ridiculously awesome piece of gear for a few
weeks so we could show it to you guys. Now

why would we show it to you all? I thought
this was a no brainer, but I did see a few

comments asking why we would show it since
it's such an expensive camera.

I think one person even said that he would
stop watching the show if we started using

this camera all the time, which is kind of
silly.

The point of this show is to try to teach
people how to make films. Most of the time

we show you how to do it with no budget, but
every now and again we're going to show you

how to do it on a much larger scale. Your
goal shouldn't be to make zero-budget films

forever. Your goal should be to learn and
practice with what you have right now so one

day, you could do things on a much bigger
scale.

So after this episode, you will hopefully
know enough about this cinema grade camera,

that you can just pick it up and go with it,
if ever the opportunity arose, so now with
that said, let's bust this beauty out.

I heard a lot about the red cameras and how
you can't use them to do run and gun shooting

or that you need a technician to come along
for a red shoot, et cetera. That is not true

at all and after this episode you'll be able
to pick one up, like I said before, and just
start shooting. So up here is the LCD.

This thing is awesome and controls the camera
through its touchscreen interface. So it makes

this camera super were easy to set-up and
get going. If you look on the LCD, you'll

see the menu up above, you just touch to change
your frames per second, your ISO, shutter,

white balance, in what resolution your shooting
at.

Right now I have it set to shoot at 5K with
the aspect ratio of 2.4 to 1. If you touch

here, though, you change it to a few other
options, including 4 k and 2 k.

I am actually shooting my action short film
in 5 k, even though I am editing and finishing

in 2 k. The reason for that is when you switch
over to 2K, the image becomes very cropped.

So, this 21 millimeter lens is looking more
like an 85 millimeter. So, there was just

no way that I was gonna shoot a fast moving
action like that, which is why I chose to
shoot in 5K.

Now moving on, if you click this little recycle-looking
sign, we move to the next area of the menu.

Over here, the only things I really had to
use much was media which is where I formatted

the cards and settings. Also down here you'll
see there is an indicator showing you where
the battery power is at.

Full is 15 volts and the camera will shut
itself off at 11V. So, you have to keep an

eye on that. It actually shut off on me mid-take.
Here you have how much space is left in your

card and then you have the histogram, then
two meters. One shows you how much noise you

have in your image and the other one shows
where the whites are clipping.

And that's the basics of all you need to know
about inside the menu of this camera.

Now, outside the camera you have the power
button, which is right here, and it also becomes

a record button once the camera is on if you
press it quickly. Then there's another record

button right here in the front. And here is
what the camera records on. These are red

mags and they are awesome. And the process
of using these is basically the same concept

as using your CS or SV card for your DSLR
cameras during production and in post.

Now, finally in front we have the lens. And
right now I have the mat box on which has

an MV filter in it, and these are Carl Zeiss
compact prime lenses. The Kessler package

comes with a few them, an 85 millimeter, a
50, a 35, and a 21. And these are just gorgeous,

super sharp, and very fast. So that is the
camera in a nutshell.

There is actually another tutorial on the
camera from Tom Guilmette online at this link

here, Tom's a great guy in super smart, so
check that out, and between his video and

mine, you will be able to pick up a Red Epic
and start shooting.

but now I've been getting a lotAsking what
48 frames per second would look like, as compared

to 24 frames per second. Since Peter Jackson
is currently shooting "The Hobbit" at 48 frames

per second, and since this is the same camera
that he is using to shoot the film, I'm going

to do some tests on both 24 and 48 to compare
the two together, but, after this.

.TV is the perfect domain name to start your
online video site. After all, who needs television

when you've got .TV. What that means is that
if you're making any kind of video that you

want to showcase off on the web, .TV domain
name is what you need. With a .TV website

you control your content and look more professional
than just using a Youtube channel.

If you want to showcase your work, you can
get seen on .TV: Just go to domain.com and

search for the perfect .TV domain for your
web site, then use the coupon code FILM right

at checkout so you can save an extra 15% of
your monies. Then, if you want to host your

.TV website, check out domain.com's hosting
plans.

They're less than six bucks a month, and they
have everything you need to build, maintain,

and promote your site. So remember, when you're
thinking "Hey! Domain names!" think domain.com

because if you have a great idea, it all starts
with a great domain. Domain.com know what

I'm saying? Domains, domain.com and ideas
for you.
Logo.

Okay and okay. So, Peter Jackson is shooting
The Hobbit at 48fps on the Red Epic and I'm

very curious to see what this is going to
look like with their process. I love when

new things are tried, and I'm super curious,
as a lot of you are, to see what it's going
to look like in the end.

So, with that in mind, I figured we would
go ahead and try putting 24 frames per second

right next to 48 frames per second to see
how different they look. Now, of course, this

will look much from their process and in the
theater projected on film, but hey, why not
give it a shot? So, let's do it.

First off, 24 frames per second. Here we are.
Start prancing about in the usual 24 frames

per. Second, and now we flip over to 48 frames
per second, again, some start action in. Good

ol' 24 frames, and again in 48 frames. Ooh,
what's this- another shot in 24 frames? And

well, how about one in 48. For the most part
I find it a little hard to tell the difference,

but when you really look you see that there's
a lot less motion blur in 48 frame clips than

there are in the 24 frame per second clips,
which I found a bit uncomfortable to watch.

But I did read that Peter Jackson has done
a lot of testing and is doing something a

little different with it. So, I'm very excited
to see and get a glimpse of, well, there technique

and how theirs look. But, yeah, did I mention
that the Red Epic shoots at 300 frames per
second? Slow motion. logo.

That's all for today my friends, but there
is more RED loving coming on Monday. We're

going to be showing my post-workflow for the
RED Epic. Plus our location scouting for the

action short film we've got coming. And it
will only get better from there so I'll see
you on Monday for more Epic goodness.
Ryan out! Holy God!

comments.author: Opti

comments.text:
+Opti I don't think it's about how much things costs here. If your 
production can afford RED, your won't be looking at numbers, you will be 
looking at possibilities. Those lenses you mentioned are indeed more 
expensive but not necessarily better. They are specific, so do their 
functions. An anamorphic Zeiss is not better than C prime because it is 
more expensive, but it is more expensive because it is anamorphic. 
Anginieux for its fixed focusing while zooming. I tend to find these 
discussions about technology quite intriguing as these subjects are so 
relative. Morevover, In two years time iphones will be shooting 6k for 
thousand bucks and so what?
comments.author: pipi333

comments.text:
+pipi333 Dunno, master/ultra primes, anamorphic Zeiss, Anginieux Zoom,... I 
even see lot's of people use red Epics with Canon L-lenses. I'm just 
wondering, why spend so much on the body and not on the lenses?

comments.text:
Oh, got it. While RED makes very good cameras there are other brands at 
much lower prices that you can use to achieve very professional quality 
videos. I currently use a Sony NEX-FS100 camera which I have no complaints 
about. My entire setup (rig, matte box, follow focus, tripod, etc.) ran me 
about $5,000. It does a bang up job of making solid videos. I know this 
doesn't help much but RED cameras are mostly owned and maintained by 
production companies, not so much private videographers or cinematographers.
comments.author: Time Legacy Productions

comments.text:
+alien craft Were you able to come up with a budget for it? Because another 
thing you can do is buy the brain, and the few necessities.
comments.author: SkintSNIPER262

comments.text: +Shea Singerling but i can't. I'm from in another country
comments.author: alien craft

comments.text:
I would rent one first. www.borrowlens.com has RED packages and usually 
runs deals to rent a camera for a week at half the price. Rent one to get 
use to it and see how the workflow is for you. Also something that is 
seldom mentioned in reviews about high end cameras is the editing process. 
Consider the need for a higher end computer to process the footage 
accordingly. I would love to own a RED but being a privateer it's just not 
feasible to buy one.
comments.author: Time Legacy Productions

comments.text:
+alien craft Also if you ever look at batteries and memory. Get the red 
brick batteries. There more expensive but they last for 2 hrs while the 
other ones only last 30mins. And memory gets pricey too. Im getting a 248GB 
card and Im bringing my laptop with me so i can transfer them on to back up 
hard drives to hold them. it takes up alot of memory. You can fill a 60GB 
card in 10 minutes on 4k.

comments.author: Vincent Leverenz

comments.text:
Hey guys. I hope Im not out of place saying this. But if someone can 
correct me. What is the significance of shooting short films on such high 
end equipment. I completely understand quality but at what cost. Im looking 
at this more from a producers stand point. If I raised $5,000 to film a 
short film I know a lot of people would want to go right away and rent or 
buy a bunch of gear. They would make an amazing little film that would look 
beautiful. But then all of their budget would be spent up. Why dont people 
just focus on managing their budget a little more and spend more towards 
the marketing and actually have their film go somewhere past vimeo, 
facebook or small indie film festival. I have a lot of respect for Film 
Riot but there smart and they can play with these toys because they know 
how to market themselves using brand integration or way of creating sources 
of income to fund this equipment and videos so they dont pay out of pocket 
for these items. ( I can only hope). People need to understand that 
marketing value is so much more important than fancy cameras. If you can 
shoot on a canon 550D. I know its not as good quality but its cheaper than 
a Scarlet, than me as a producer would rather invest my funds into a film I 
know might go somewhere with filmmakers who need pretty equipment and don't 
have the talent to film frugal. Thats what separates Hollywood from 
Independent filmmakers. I know its an unfortunate world we live in but if 
you want to get past the Independant status you have to think corporate and 
what will sell. Your audience doesnt care on wether this was shot on a dslr 
or cinematic camera. As long as it looks GOOD and is entertaining. Think of 
how Spielberg and Cameron were making films in the early days without all 
this stuff. ﻿
comments.author: John Quintana

comments.text:
Every film maker has different goals, and different standers in mind when 
shooting films. No one is wrong for paying more to get the best out of 
there work. I love the way the Red footage looks, and i have a friend that 
has a friend that for some reason just has a Red sitting around that's not 
getting used that much, and said we can use it for free to shoot with if we 
want, but i told him that i feel the Red is over kill, and we don't need 
it. I can shoot great videos with out it, plus the Red is heavy. We where 
just shooting a music video, and the 5d mark ii, or even a t2i dose great 
jobs on music videos so i did not see any need to use the Red, but maybe 
for a small film i would. Some times on bigger projects you want every edge 
you can get. I'm just saying its a time to use Red, and its a time not too. 
Just cause the footage looks great and the Red cost a lot dose not mean its 
all ways the best tool for the job, but some times its is the best, and the 
go to tool for the job.
comments.author: tyquan1000finest

comments.text:
+gabriel medel I agree. For a lot of us at this beginning stage in the 
filmmaking world, we're not doing it to make money. We're doing to do what 
we love and tell a story to entertain an audience.
comments.author: EagleWeek

comments.text:
As a producer stand point, you're probably right, but from an artistic 
standpoint, there's so much more you can do on a Scarlet than a Canon 
camera. Often these cameras have higher quality sensors, and thus can be 
manipulated in post to create a more cinematic product.

comments.text:
In short....1080p = 1920 X 1080....OR.....1920 horizontal pixels X 1080 
vertical pixels (just shy of 2K). 4K = 3840 X 2160 5K = 5120 X 2700 Its a 
MUCH higher resolution within the picture that you are seeing. Which means 
you can blow it up on a much bigger screen without losing any resolution.

comments.author: rockhopper123452

comments.text:
Making myself look like an idiot? Learn how to properly spell and punctuate 
a sentence before you talk. I never said i post 4K videos and why are you 
looking at my channel? You said you edit in 1/8 which is not 4k. To handle 
4k you need to have a 4K monitor, Stable frame rates at a live full 4k 
video and it has to be running without any lag at all. Thats what handling 
4k means not editing 4k. Any computer can edit 4k but it will take longer 
on ones than others.
comments.author: rockhopper123452

comments.text:
good thinking. leave before you make yourself look like an idiot. telling

youd know whats necessary for 4k with your C4D title tuts.
comments.author: RLfilmz

comments.text:
You know what never mind im not going to argue with you. There is so much

comments.text:
thats cute that you say that, because it does. like i said, i edit at 1/4 
or 1/8 anyway, which is the equivalent of editing in 1080p at full res. 
either way, it can be output to 4k when im done. maybe you should ask 
before you make assumptions and make yourself look like a retard. lol i 
cant believe this dude just told me what my computer can and cant handle 
with no knowledge of my setup or workflow.
comments.author: RLfilmz

comments.text: Your hackintosh cannot handle 4k.
comments.author: rockhopper123452

comments.text:
well then id suggest you check your full load temps for all 8 threads 
because it shouldnt take you that long to render, nor should working with 
4k be such a chore. are you using CUDA? check your drive SATA settings. 
AHCI works much better than IDE. something is wrong with your system. good 
luck figuring it out. feel free to ask me if you cant figure it out.
comments.author: RLfilmz

comments.text: i have a 4770k clocked at 4ghz and 16gb 1600mhz ram
comments.author: BijouCinema

comments.text:
oh and i render 3-4 minute music videos with multiple layers, channels, 
dynamic link footage, effects, titles etc in 1080p and it takes under 4 
hours to do a full quality prores422 dual pass. i did a 12 minute BTS video 
for a movie premiere and that took under 10 hours. you either have a 
serious computer problem, or you got ripped off when you bought your pc.
comments.author: RLfilmz

comments.text:
like i said, you probably have a problem with your system. and its not a 
mac. its a hackintosh. its a 3570k overclocked to 4.4Ghz or a z77 
motherboard. 32gb 1600mhz, closed loop liquid cooling (H60 - discontinued) 
and im running a pretty dated gpu...9800gt 1024mb. i have all of my live 
rendering and gpu processes split between the integrated gpu and the 
dedicated card. actually just under $866 and some change in total. a little 
technical knowledge goes a long way
comments.author: RLfilmz

comments.text:
What Mac do you have. 900$ is plain silly if you are saying it is good for 
4k. not even my computer can handel 4k renders. a simple 1080p 2 min render 
takes about 30 hours to render. how the heck can yours render something and 
still have a steady work flow
comments.author: BijouCinema

comments.text:
you seem to have editing and compositing confused. i said i edit at 1/4 or 
1/8 (because then i dont need to render). when im in after effects or maya 
im full res. and 4k isnt that bad unless you just have poor system 
management. i can work in 4k in full res just fine in after effects with my 
$900 computer. so either you have ridiculously high latency ram or you cpu 
is getting too hot and downclocking itself to keep from burning pins, or 
you just dont manage your system %s very well.
comments.author: RLfilmz

comments.text:
if u are still needing to edit in 1/4 or 1/8 its still bad. editing isnt 
just cuttign a movie. some times like me (a film maker) i have to render 
special effects and 3D simulations, 4k is a bitch to work with unless you 
have something reaching the $2,000's any ways check out my channel @ 
Th3filmclub if you want to see what kinda things i film
comments.author: BijouCinema

comments.text:
my $900 hackintosh handles 4k just fine. i can only run 1 full res stream 
at a time, but i usually edit at 1/4 or 1/8 anyway, so thats 4-8 
simultaneous streams. post for 4k is pretty doable for most people now.
comments.author: RLfilmz

comments.text: yes. this isnt the issue tho. the issue is workflow right now

comments.author: BijouCinema

comments.text:
4K doesn't necessarily mean REAL cinema movies. 4K is basically the quality 
of a video. 5K in definition takes in a lot more information (hence the 
bigger gulps of precious megabytes it takes per second), 4K takes a lot 
less, and the list goes on til' you get to the average 360 and 240p. A 10 
minute video of 240p should give you about 4-5mb. A 4K counterpart would go 
as much as 3-5GB due to the information. I might be giving false file 
sizes, but in a nutshell it should give you similar figures
comments.author: NeilFX

comments.text:

have some kind of effect on how Youtube processes it?
